description:
Players compete to defeat enemies with their ninja hand seals. The top two contenders perform a final battle in real-time to determine a winner.

Enemy cards are laid out on the table. Then ninja hand seal cards are laid out surrounding the enemy cards. Simultaneously, players must collect the hand seals depicted on their chosen enemy card, taking care to make sure they are arranged in the correct order. Once a player has claimed all the ninja hand seal cards, they must grab the chosen enemy, followed by the ninja token.

After their card order has been determined to be correct, the player must perform the shout and hand seals in the proper rhythm. If the other players judge the chant and hand signs to be correct, the enemy is defeated without a curse. If there are any mistakes, the enemy is defeated, but the player is also cursed with negative points.

Play continues until all the enemies have been defeated. The players add their white and black seals, and whichever is least is their score. The two highest scoring players then perform a final ninja hand seal battle to determine who is the ultimate master.

25 OUTLAWS – OLD WEST POKER WITH OUTLAW RULES a new card game from CHICKAPIG game creator Brian Calhoun and Dave Matthews.  While based on the classic game of poker, 25 OUTLAWS offers a fun, Wild West twist. It’s a rough-and-tumble game set in the Old West, with outlaws (players) using every means available to eliminate rival outlaw gangs. With duels, bank robberies and more, 25 OUTLAWS is bringing new meaning to the term “high stakes.” While on tour, Dave Matthews drew all of the art for the game – from the chips and cards to the outlaw illustrations on the box cover.

—description from the publisher

Theme:
FlipTales is a party game for creative people! In FlipTales, you and your friends pretend to be different magical characters in a story, working together to advance the plot. It's like Mad-Libs meets Choose-Your-Own-Adventure.

Game-play:
In each story, one person is the wiz. In each scene of the story, the wiz reads out a prompt, and then the rest of the players freestyle in response.
In freestyle, players go in a circle and act out responses to the prompt. Then, they flip their coins in the air. If they get enough heads, they succeed. the wiz decides how many is enough.
If your character gets damaged, you have to give up strength coins. Lose them all, and you die. There's a lot of danger in the world of FlipTales so watch out

Game setup:
- STEP 1: Choose Wiz
They read the story and decide the result of the players' flips.
- STEP 2: Create characters
Everyone else gets 1 creature card and 1 ability card. Your character is the combination of these two cards.
- STEP 3: Grab coins
Grab the coins indicated on your cards and combine them. When you use your strength, magic, or smarts in the game, flip all your coins of that colour.(or use normal coins with the print & play version)
- STEP 4: Pick a story from the storybook
Hand it to the wiz. (start with the tutorial the first time)

Goal:
In FlipTales, you and your friends pretend to be different magical creatures in a story. You win when you get to the end of the story.

—description from the designer

The Bourbon Run is a bourbon trivia board game for bourbon enthusiasts. Challenge your knowledge of America's native spirit with this one-of-a-kind trivia board game.
It includes trivia, quotes, history, the production process, and much more. The board resembles a horse track and each furlong feature a craft distillery. Hand-made tokens and high-quality materials make this a must-own game for all bourbon lovers.

Roll the die to move around the track. If you land on a distillery you get to answer a multiple choice or true/false trivia question. Answer incorrectly and you move back a space. Land on a Cooperage Barrell space and you discover a new piece of trivia and move on the board according to the card. The first player around the race track who answers a trivia question correctly is the winner.

Return to Carvania in the follow-up to Century: Golem Edition.

In Century: Golem Edition – Eastern Mountains, players resume their roles as crystal traders and are now out exploring the Carvania mountain ranges and associated valleys seeking to establish a trade network.

Century Golem: Eastern Mountains reimplements Century: Eastern Wonders but with vivid manga-inspired art. Explore the new gameplay elements and combine this game with Century: Golem Edition to play the unique game "The Call for Adventure."

Followers is a hardcore eurogame combining two epic subjects — mythology and time travel.

In Followers, you become one of the mythological gods and travel to different epochs to convert as many people as possible to your faith. Make your Followers build the Symbols of Faith in your honor, using conjoint and finite resources of the planet.

On your turn, you can place your five Avatars (in the game they are represented by miniatures) on the empty space on the board and do a corresponding action. You can also pay resources to initiate the construction of the Symbols of Space or use your special God power. All of the above actions create powerful combos, making you more and more powerful.
 The game play is tricky: resources used in the Past expire in the Present and Future. A unique electronic device helps to micromanage the whole process. Instead of counting, players just need to press a button.

The winner of the game is the player, who has converted the most Followers.

—description from publisher

Players compete to complete illustrations of garden scenes by being the first to collect the nine tiles shown on their board.

Two methods of play are provided. In method one, players draw tiles face down from the top of either the draw pile or discard pile in hopes of finding tile that matches their board. In method two, all tiles are spread face down on the table and on a players turn they may secretly view any tile they wish, keeping any that match their board.

Garden Lotto was designed for The National Trust and features illustrations representative of the different types of garden found in the British Isles from Tudor times to the nineteenth century. Similar gardens can be seen in many National Trust properties.

—user summary

The dawn of a new age approaches and we stand at the precipice. The unbridled power of nature awakens something within. Mysteries demand to be explored and the results are not always what we expect. Creepy creatures, dangerous devices, precarious potions, CoLaboratory Incorporated provides a shared laboratory space that is the perfect home for your and your outlandish creations.

Build interesting devices that open new possibilities. Brew potions that grant you fantastic on-demand abilities. Create strange monsters and earn great renown. All while keeping an eye on your fellow scientist and their minions. Scientists bring research into the lab to use on their experiments but they are not the only ones who benefit. Occupy a space adjacent to the research dice held by any minion and you can use it for your own creations.

Collect monster, device, or potion dice to generate more research that can be used on your creations.

Expand the laboratory giving everyone new opportunities.

With each new creation, your collection grows and the placement of each creation in your grid can create new opportunities or gain more renown. Once a player builds their 12th creation the end of the game is triggered and the player with the most renown (points) wins.

CoLab worker and dice placement game with dice collection. Players compete to gain the most renown through building monster, device, or potion cards over the course of the game. Each turn you send a minion to a tower space to gather resources or return a minion. Your minions also hold your resource dice. This resource can be used by players at either adjacent laboratory location. Then you place your player miniature on a laboratory location and either put the adjacent minions to work collecting more resources or build cards according to what is available at that lab. As the game progresses the board expands giving new opportunities for all players who visit that location.

Build a wide variety of monsters, potions, and devices or focus on one type to gain the most renown and win the game.

CoLab employs a series of '“take this”' mechanics where players provide resources, minions, or other opportunities to their opponents in exchange for resources or points. Balancing how much you give away with the opportunities your opponents may create is the real trick to becoming the most renowned scientist in CoLab.

—description from the publisher

Cowboy Bebop: Space Serenade is a competitive deck-building game with 2 to 4 players in which you play one of the four members of the famous Bebop crew.

Each player tries to prove that he is the best bounty hunter by getting the most reputation points at the end of the game. To do so, they will have to capture the criminals wanted by the ISSP, in a spirit of limited collaboration.

During the game, players will be able to buy cards that will allow them to improve their personal deck, in order to better manage the resources necessary for their victory. They will also be able to move from planet to planet with gas or use their special abilities and even those of other players if they have in the same place as them.

The game ends when the terrible Vicious is captured or has fled.

—description from publisher

Majority is a game of words association mixed with a mechanism of push your luck.
Every turn, the players must secretly vote for the most logical association between one word and three propositions. Once the votes revealed, the majority association is determined. Players voted for that proposition keep on playing with another turn. When there only two players left, those players receive points.
When a player reaches 20 points, the game is over.

Buying this fabled map was a stroke of genius. The most ancient, legendary, and extravagant underwater wrecks are waiting for divers. Diving suits and oxygen tanks are aboard, and the ship is ready to weigh anchor. There's no time to lose! The increased hustle and bustle of the harbor, with ship captains attempting to hire the best divers and historians, can mean only one thing: Other captains have the same map, and the biggest treasure hunt of all time is about to begin!

Deep Blue is a press-your-luck and engine-building, family game in which players dive for wealth and may join and benefit from other player's diving fortunes. In this game, players have to collect the right crew of divers, sailors, and archeologists, race to wreck sites to claim the best spots to dive from, and scout the seas to discover new wrecks. Players have to take risks if they want to be the most wealthy diver!

—description from the publisher

Sky Riders is a considerably rare space board game from Parker Brothers. It is dated as a 1940 release in the book American Games (Alex Malloy, 2000) and was featured in a series of advertisements in four consecutive December 1940 issues of Life Magazine.

The object of the game is for players to move around the solar system collecting the rare element, Coronium, and then return it to Earth without it being stolen by other players. Bags of Coronium are represented by yellow or green discs.

Each player starts with a small coloured wooden token (their Miner). Players move through the orbits of different planets based on the roll of two dice. A player collects Coronium by landing on a planet and then throwing a particular number associated with that planet.

When a Miner with five or more bags (discs) of Coronium lands on Mars, it becomes a Martian Raider. The small Miner token is exchanged for a large wooden token of the same colour. The Martian Raider can then capture Coronium from another player by landing directly on the player's Miner.

To win the game, a player must arrive back on Earth, by exact count, with 15 or more bags of Coronium.

Ages ago, before history, before humans walked the earth, ancient beings ruled the darkest corners of the cosmos from beyond. Their earliest followers harnessed fragments of their immeasurable power in earthly objects. Chaos and destruction spread throughout the land leaving no family untouched by darkness. A great war ensued and these once great objects of cosmic power became lost and forgotten in time…

You lied to the other scientists on the expedition to Am’harb, an uninhabited island in the Pacific. Only you, a true servant of the Ancient Ones, is powerful enough to move the deadly dark towers surrounding the island.

Manipulate the towers to strategically scatter your priests and cultists around the island and gain control of the dark altars. Excavate esoteric resources left behind by lost civilizations. Wisely exchange them for the cosmic powers of the Ancient One to advance your position.

Can you solve the Towers of Am’harb and unlock the secrets before your rivals? Do this before the other cults to ensure you and you alone lead humanity from the deadly light and into the peace and safety of a new dark age!

Gameplay Overview

In Towers of Am’harb, you are a leader of a doom cult, and you are competing with others just like you, all trying to unleash the Ancient One of their worship to conquer the world!

Players will take turns moving their set of 4 different sized discs, manipulating them according to the rules of the mathematical puzzle toy Tower of Hanoi/Brahma. Then you send your followers(disciples) to the 2 columns you just moved a disc into, in order to gain control of scoring altars that provide doom points at the end of the game. Your followers come in different sizes, 3 priests which provides 3 influence, and 6 cultists which provides 1 influence; each follower spreads influence to the 8 surrounding spaces, so it can influence more than one altar.

Since players will sit and play their discs on different orthogonal sides of the map, the result is that the vertical columns you can play into will be the horizontal rows of the next player, and generates to very interesting interactions. When playing your followers on to the board, you will need also to pay a cost depending on how crowded the area you are entering, which can be offset by the height of your towers, so you must plan ahead on where you need to concentrate your efforts.

There are 8 different Lovecraftian Ancient Ones to worship in this game, each with a different Cosmic Power for players to rely on. The map is made from dual-sided modular boards, with different layouts for 2/3/4 player scaling; you can start with symmetric distribution of scoring altars, or flip them around for dynamic asymmetric layouts.

The game ends when the first player plays all 9 of their followers to the board, then all other players gets to take one more turn. Then players resolves each altar on the board one by one and give out doom points to the players with highest influence. The player who accumulates the highest doom points awakens the Ancient One of their worship, and releases unfathomable cosmic horror upon the world.

Disclaimer: Moaideas Game Design is not liable for the unexpected or premeditated summoning of any Ancient One or Elder God and in no way endorses or condones belief or membership of any doom cult. All hail, Cthulhu.

Adventurers fight tirelessly in service of the realm, but all work and no play makes for weary travelers, so come one, come all to the Manderville Gold Saucer — an amusement facility where you can take a break and regain the energy to face your next adventure head on!

Final Fantasy XIV: Gold Saucer Cactpot Party is a board game reimagining of the Mini Cactpot, a popular attraction found within the Manderville Gold Saucer! Gather your friends and challenge this new party game!

—description from the publisher

Orion’s Spur is a starship battle game where you take command of a species’ fleet and show off your tactical superiority on the battlefield by defeating your opponents in combat.

Using your species's tactics and innate abilities, target your opponents ships to earn their worth in victory points. But be careful. Every species has their own tricks to minimize your damage or even counterattack! There are reinforcements on the way, but will they make it in time when you're low on energy and down to your last ship?

Stay strong and score the most victory points to prove your tactical skills are the best!

—description from the designer

This is a game for 3 men (agents) and 3 women (assistants).
The agents are the active players, while the female assistants watch over the rules and serve alcoholic drinks to the agents.

Each player has 3 Agents (caps) which enter the game board (Paris) from different directions. Movement is determinet by a roulette disc.

If an agent gets on a space with an opponents agent, the later is captured. If an agent gets on a space with a red dot, the player has to draw an assignment card. If he has captured another agent, he may chose to set him free and the released agent has to fulfill the assignment. Some assignments benefit or hinder the agent, others cause the player to take off his clothes or kiss his female assistant.

The first player to reach Montmartre with 2 agents and one captured agent wins the game.

—user summary

The Godzilla Card Game uses the Chrono Clash turn and resource system, which allows players to strategically use their resources and accurately represents the flow of real battles, with momentum shifting from player to player as they choose the best time to throw their big moves! Lie in wait by setting sneaky traps for your opponent, or seize the initiative for a game-ending attack! The Chrono Clash system allows for players' favorite characters from different IPs to join the fray!

ÐÑÑ‚Ñ€Ð¾Ð½Ð°Ð²Ñ‚Ñ‹ (Astronauts) is soviet era space exploration game where players travel through the cosmos before returning to earth. The game dates from around 1970 determined by an image of a first generation Soyuz spacecraft (1967 - 1971) on the playing board.

Through the roll of the dice players first travel through the solar system before moving through the zodiac constellations. Certain numbered spots provide benefits or setbacks on their travel. Zodiacal cards are also obtained in specific constellation that also give or deduct points.

The winner of the game is the first to return to earth.

—user summary

Doublehead Kids is a card game for four (or more persons), which depicts the “Doppelkopf” normal game with cards suitable for children. The game is suitable for players from about 6 years (the numbers from 1 to 20 must be read and recognized independently) and lasts about 30-45 minutes or 60-90 minutes, depending on the chosen winning score.

The “Doppelkopf”-Game is one of the most popular German card games, which finds more and more enthusiastic fans and supporters, who organize themselves in clubs and even in a German umbrella organization (DDV). Doppelkopf even manages to replace the extremely popular game Skat as the favourite card game of the Germans. Doppelkopf probably originated from the game “Schafkopf”, which already had a set of rules since 1895. Doppelkopf got its name from the fact that all cards in the game are doubled. DOUBLEHEAD KIDS for 4 players consists of 48 playing cards. The playing cards have differently displayed strengths (shield symbol at the top left), which determine the ranking of the card and silver winning coins, which represent the winning value of a card. Furthermore the cards are assigned to four different family coats of arms (colours): the royal family with the red crown sign (26 cards), the black princely families with cross and spades signs (8 cards each) and the red princely family with the heart sign (6 cards). The royal family’s cards are trumps.

The four players form two teams: the players with the princesses/prince pair and the players without the princesses/prince pair. As a game goal, each team tries to bag more silver winning coins than the opposing team. A total of 240 silver winning coins can be collected in a game round with 12 duels (tricks). The team with at least 121 silver winning coins wins the round and receives victory points in the form of gold coins. Furthermore, additional victory points can be gained through special points.

The special attraction of the double-headed game is that at the beginning of a new round the players do not know with whom they are playing. Only when the princess and the prince are laid out bit by bit, the picture becomes clearer for the players and the other players recognize in which team they are playing. Each game round is different and takes place in different player combinations. It is forbidden to signal to other players whether you are playing together in a team by verbal utterances or sign language. It is very well allowed to send playful signals to your fellow players by tactically laying out cards (e.g. deliberately re-buttering silver winning points into a duel or not). Bluffing is also allowed here, of course, to create confusion.

—description from the designer

A brilliant test of lateral thinking! Players battle it out to move from one corner of the grid to another by rotating, flipping and sliding Tyles to link up the path and create a route to victory.

Be warned! Your opponents can sabotage you by moving the Tyles to cut off your route. Will you be able to find a winning strategy first?

—description from the publisher

Glued to your phone screen? All about that #blessed life? Then grab your friends for a hilarious game of #SocialBingo.

Take turns to read out cards with different statements on, anything from "Your last message contained an emoji" to "You have over fifty matches on a dating app." If you have that matching icon on your bingo board and, more importantly, you're able to provide phone evidence to prove what's written on the card, you can mark that icon off the board.

Who will be the first to get three in a row and who will be left unfriended.

—description from the publisher

Can you draw a picture of Kim Kardashian playing croquet on a trampoline? Or Tarzan drinking a martini on the Golden Gate Bride? Or perhaps a Playboy Bunny riding a unicycle on a sun lounger?

Show off your creative flair with this crazy game of doodles! Players battle to sketch out hilarious scenes for their teams to guess based on the topic cards. Will your teammates recognize your artistic genius, or will you be a doodling disaster?

—description from the publisher

A parody game of real-world presidency election of the USA.
The players compete to get most of the votes in order to step up to become the president.
Appeals to audience of the intriguing question on how the electoral system should work in a democratic setting
Focuses on inculcating virtues like integrity and fairness in a civilized world.
The players are expected to use treacherous approaches, throwing curve ball strategies to outrun others.

—description from the designer

You have been called to face worthy opponents in a contest of strategy and cunning. Armed with amulet tiles and dual-direction gems, your goal is to align colors to score points. You may only lay a tile if you have a matching gem to place within it, so plan your moves wisely. Legendary players align three or more amulets of a matching color to score bonus points. Earn the most points and you will be richly rewarded as the victor! For 2 to 4 players. Contains 60 tiles, 60 gems and rules.

—description from the publisher

Simple game of skill for 2 people. Players takes turns of placing a marble in a slot against a plunger and catapulting the ball along a curved ski ramp where the ball becomes airborne. If the correct force is applied the marble lands in a concentric scoring zone marked 30,20 or 10 points.

The object of the game is to exactly score 100 points. If the player goes over 100 points they must start again.

—user summary

Oh no, bacilli as far as the eye can see: In game "Bacteria Hysteria" Halskratzi, Schnupfentierchen, Bauchgrummelo and Co. swirling around in front of the other players around. On the cards, on the dice, practically everywhere the danger lurks. Although they look cute and harmless, they do not want anyone. Only those who dice well and act quickly can get rid of many of the microscopic creatures. For even more thrills, the 40-second timer, which works relentlessly.

In the middle of the table is a stack of 108 cards and 10 dice. From each side of the dice one of the six different colored bacilli grins cheekily into the round. Before you can start, each player places six cards face down in front of him. Now the youngest player grabs the dice, activates the timer and quickly turns his cards on. To get rid of these, he needs at least two identical bacilli and at least two cube images of the corresponding bacillus, about two green ear cucumbers or three gray-purple cough monsters. Was Fortuna merciful? Then two, three or even more of these Bazillenkarten come to a pile and new ones are drawn. It will be diced again until the timer jumps into the air after 40 seconds.

In turn, once each of the two to four players (from six years) on the train, is scored. Who made the most cards and routed most bacilli? Jackpot - the first winning chip is conquered, with three chips you win the fast dice game for the whole family, which requires a good eye-hand coordination and raises the body temperature from the hustle and bustle - even without "Fieberchen".

Miss Cornfield and her class are in danger at Winterstein School! But Mr. Morrison from the magical pet store knows advice. Players help magical animals make their way to the pet store. For if an animal is discovered, it petrifies and can not be moved further. Only when the players work together, they can manage to win. The game becomes exciting through event cards and the turntable. A great board game that will not only please fans of the "School of Magical Animals".

This simple push-your-luck game is basically an adaptation of Diamant/Incan Gold for play with the Green Box of Games game system.

Play:
Each turn, a new card is turned up on the table. The number on the card denotes how many gold nuggets are to be found. Now each player must decide whether to continue or flee, before the next card is turned up.

Players that run away get to collect and divide all the treasure left on the cards. They are then out of the game for the rest of the round.

Play continues until all players have left, or until three cards with identical symbols have been placed on the table. Then the cavern collapses, and any players remaining inside will lose all the treasure they collected this round.

Winner:
After 4 rounds, count the total gemstones each player has collected. The winner is the player with the most gold.

—description from the designer

This card based race game is an adaptation of Cartagena for play with the Green Box of Games game system.

Build a track of tiles with the six different symbols spaced out. Each player controls one or more cubes and is dealt one or more cards (the number of cubes and cards can be adjusted to your preferred level of complexity)

To move you play a card and then move one of your cubes forward until it reaches an available tile matching the symbol of the card you played. If the tile is occupied by another player you keep moving to the next match. The winner is the first to reach the end of the track with all their cubes.

—description from the designer

To the Death is a tactical skirmish game for one to two players. It uses hand management, action selection, draft, and area control mechanics.

In To the Death, each player controls one hero from each of the four classes: Champions, Fighters, Magicians, and Menders. Each hero has three abilities and may be activated once per turn. Combining these abilities to have the maximum effect is the key to victory.

The two player mode is a competitive skirmish battle between each player's heroes. The solo mode employs a two enemy decks of monsters and monster kings which battle the heroes. As monsters are defeated, they add new abilities to the undefeated monsters, including the ultra-deadly monster king.

To the Death features 264 cards including: 176 heroes, 64 monsters, 44 monster kings, and 16 hero damage cards which grant heroes abilities as they fight. 190 cards were created by backers during the Kickstarter campaign.

You can play 44 times without repeating any heroes or monster kings.

—description from the designer

Paper Pinball is a dice game that tries to capture the feeling of playing pinball. All you will need is a pencil, three dice, and about five minutes.

Each round, roll two dice and fill in one of the scoring zones. Some zones need to be filled in a certain way, and most will cause some sort of effect, so the order you fill them in is important. If you ever can't fill a zone, you'll lose a ball. Lose three balls and the game is over. Try to fill as many scoring zones as possible while triggering multipliers, opening tunnels, and getting the coveted multiball.

—description from the publisher

Developed to be played with the Green Box of Games game system.

In Flower Garden you compete to create the most beautiful garden. Play your cards in the shop to acquire flowers, or use them to create beds to plant you flowers in. And make sure you get all your flowers planted, or they will dry out and reduce your score.

—description from the designer

Aujourd' Hui Dans L'Espace - Un Voyage Dans La Lune (Today in Space - A Journey into the Moon) is a 1960's French space game where players launch rockets into space to land on other worlds and then return them to earth (square 59).

The objective is to land 4 rockets on the moon, Mars, Jupiter and Saturn and return to earth first collecting points along the way.

The quirky thing about the game is how the rockets advance on the board. To advance a rocket, one adds the numbered square the rocket is on with the result from a roulette wheel spin. E.g If a rockets sits on square 6 and the roulette spin is a 2 they may advance to square 8. Problem is there is only 25 squares on the board so a player could remain on a spot if the number spun on the roulette wheel adds up to a number not found on the board. In addition, the numbered squares are either black or red, with red holding unpleasant surprises.

The winner is the player to return their rockets to earth and to have accumulated the highest number of points.

Welcome in dressrosa! The straw hat crew sneak into dressrosa and divide into three teams; destroying artificial Devil fruit factory team, escorting caeser team and securing thousand sunny team. In this special one piece edition of Monopoly, you'll visit all the characters of the Anime one piece as well as trying to get Koala and soldier over to your side! Chest and flag cards might reward you for fights against the villains or bring an unexpected surprise... Buy, sell and trade with other fans to get a powerful one piece team and win the game!


     The world's favourite family Board Game brings this exciting edition of One Piece Monopoly
     Choose your favourite bespoke One Piece character playing token and tour your favourite One Piece characters
     Advance to Bellamy, Violet, or even Luffy - will you owe rent or reap the rewards?
     Build your house and hotels and trade your way to success
     The Fast-Dealing Property Trading Game is fun for the whole family


—description from the publisher

Body Talk is a family party game where players act out words, without talking, using only certain body parts while the other players try to guess the word.

—descriptions from publisher

The Kickstarter edition includes the base game as well as The Alchemist's Garden Expansion which is packaged inside the box of the base game.

The expansion adds eighteen more cards for your games of Weird Alchemy.

9 new creatures in three new sets.
3 new magic cards.
6 extra pass cards.

The expansion allows the game to be played by up to eight players.

-description from designer

Twinkle Twinkle the games of stars is a simple children's game from the 1930's with a celestial theme.

The game board consist of 40 coloured stars. Each star holds a same coloured peg. A spinner is central in the board and a player spins the arrow and removes a coloured peg indicated by the arrow. A white spot on the spinner results in players putting pegs back.

When all pegs are removed from the board, players count their pegs and the most pegs is the winner.

—user summary

The Only Word is a vivid party word game that brings your imagination and creativity to a new level and guarantees ultimate fun. Inspired by Codenames, the game features the best advantages of compact travel tabletop games – very easy to explain, very dynamic and can be played even on the way without a table. Other key advantages of the game – all the players are in the game all the time and you get both competitive (each player plays for himself) and cooperative modes in one box.

How to play the game: 

     Take your cards in hand as your personal deck, and move the first card slightly down. The numbers of the second card indicate the words of the first card - they are your challenge!
     Describe (or rather bridge) your challenge words with a one-word clue. The players have an option to choose how many challenge words (2 or 3) they will bridge.
     Speak out your clue and show your card - other players should rack their brains to be the first who guess all the words you described. 


The players have only one try to show how shrewd they are. The first player to solve the clue discards one of his cards. The goal of the game is to get rid of all the cards.

Why the game is so cute: 

     easy game rules, that can be explained in 1 minute - it’s a perfect family game;
     you don’t need a table to play the game, so you can take it wherever you want;
     it is very dynamic, all the players are in the game every turn; 
     the game has both competitive (3+) and cooperative (2+) modes;
     two difficulty levels; 
     the game is bilingual: the words on the cards are in the English and in the Russian languages (for the Russian edition). You can play in one of the  languages or in both;
     very replayable with the total of 1008 words on the cards. 


—description from the designer

Eliminate your friends and fight your way to the top in this highly-strategic, fast-paced card game! Hit your rivals with hammers, and dance away from incoming Hits. Unlock power cards by collecting 3 of a kind to heal yourself and to go on rampages. Play individually or in teams (Beware of friendly fire!), but don't forget to laugh in the face of the losers with a loud "Bruhaha."

—description from the publisher

Trails of Tucana is a flip-and-write game from the creators of Avenue and Doodle City that is quick and easy to play, but has enough depth to entertain gamers.

Each player is given a map of the island Tucana, showing its villages and important sights. The positions of the villages are randomized for each player, so every game will provide a unique puzzle.

Each turn, one player flips over two terrain cards. Each player must draw — on their own map — a trail between two neighboring spaces of the shown terrains. Gradually, the trails will grow into a network of roads. Players score points by connecting matching harbors, and by connecting sights to harbors. Being the first to connect a pair of harbors provides bonus points.

To add depth to the game, there are varying distribution of the different terrain cards. Mountain cards are for instance rarer than desert cards, so it would be harder to build a trail through a mountain range or over water than through desert or forest. Players need to take this into account when planning their routes. And they should maximize the probability that they will be able to make use of any combination of terrain cards that may come up.

—description from designer

AWARDS AND HONORS:

2021 Finnish Game of the Year (family) WINNER
2020 Norwegian Game of the Year WINNER
2020 Norwegian Game of the Year NOMINEE
2019 The Dice Tower SEAL OF EXCELLENCE

Components: 54 (2 × Alphabet/2 × Pun)

Object of the game

The object of the game is to form one or more words on your own hand. The score of a word results from the number of letters. Example: The word "GAME" consists of four letters and thus results in four points. The words "TURN" and "CARD" result in four plus four points, i.e. a total of eight points. The player with the most points on his hand wins.

Pun Rules

The starting order can be determined by lots. The player who draws the highest card in the alphabet begins. First, each player is dealt six cards face down. The remaining cards are dealt face down in the center as the deck. Three cards from the deck are dealt face up in the center. There must always be three cards in the center throughout the game.

Phase 1
The active player may swap an unlimited number of cards with the other players in the first phase. You may also exchange several cards for one.

Phase 2
The active player can then choose between these three options:
1. The player can swap one or more cards from the center with those in his hand and then end his turn.
2. The player can draw a card from the deck and end his turn. This option cannot be selected if there is no more card in the deck.
3. The player can end the round. This ends his turn. The round continues until  all other players have completed their turn Now the points of each player are counted.

All words in the dictionary are allowed. Abbreviations and names are not allowed. Players can also agree to allow words in other languages or limit themselves to terms from a specific subject area (e.g. animals). The „Pun- card“ is the wild card and can represent any one of the 26 letters.

-description from designer

Pun Spielanleitung

Karten: 54 (2 × Alphabet/2 × Pun)

Anleitung: Deutsch und Englisch

Anzahl Spieler: 2–8

Altersgruppe: ab 6 Jahren

Autor: Bastian Ruhl

Ziel des Spiels

Ziel des Spiels ist es, ein Wort oder mehrere Wörter auf der eigenen Hand zu bilden. Die Punktzahl eines Wortes ergibt sich aus der Anzahl der Buchstaben (also jeder Buchstabe ist grundsätzlich gleich viel Wert). Beispiel: Das Wort „SPIEL“ besteht aus fünf Buchstaben und ergibt somit fünf Punkte. Die Wörter „ZUG“ und „KARTE“ ergeben drei und fünf Punkte, also insgesamt acht Punkte. Derjenige Spieler, der am Ende die meisten Punkte auf der Hand hat, gewinnt.

Finaler Sieger: Man kann danach Spielen wer nach einer bestimmten Anzahl an Runden die meisten Punkte hat oder wer der Sieger der meisten Runden ist.

Pun-Spielregeln

Wer anfängt, kann ausgelost werden. Der Mitspieler, der die höchste Karte im Alphabet zieht, beginnt. Zuerst bekommt jeder Spieler sechs Karten verdeckt ausgeteilt. Die restlichen Karten werden, als Stapel verdeckt, in die Mitte gelegt. Drei Karten vom Stapel werden offen in die Mitte gelegt. Während des gesamten Spiels müssen immer drei Karten in der Mitte liegen. Der Spielzug eines Spielers besteht aus zwei Phasen.

Phase 1

Der aktive Spieler darf in der ersten Phase mit den anderen Spielern unbegrenzt viele Karten tauschen (verbal und darf verdeckt oder offen stattfinden). Es dürfen auch mehrere Karten gegen eine getauscht werden (bis man selbst nicht mehr tauschen möchte oder die anderen Spieler nicht mehr tauschen möchten). Das Tauschen von Karten ist ein wichtiges strategisches Element und sollte nicht vernachlässigt werden.

Phase 2

Anschließend muss sich der aktive Spieler zwischen drei Möglichkeiten entscheiden:

1. Er kann eine oder mehrere Karten aus der Mitte mit denen auf seiner Hand tauschen und den Zug beenden.

2. Oder der Spieler kann eine Karte vom Stapel ziehen und den Zug beenden. Diese Option ist nicht wählbar, wenn keine Karte mehr im Stapel ist.

3. Der Spieler kann das Spiel beenden. Dadurch ist der Zug beendet. Das Spiel läuft noch eine Runde weiter und endet, sobald der Spieler, der es beendet hat, wieder am Zug wäre. Nun werden die Punkte gezählt.

Die Umlaute Ä, Ö, Ü werden durch AE, OE, UE gebildet und das áºž durch SS. Alle im Duden stehenden Wörter sind erlaubt. Abkürzungen und Namen sind hingegen nicht gestattet. Die Spieler können sich aber auch darauf einigen, Wörter anderer Sprachen zu erlauben oder sich nur auf Begriffe aus einem bestimmten Themenfeld zu beschränken (z. B. Tiere) (siehe Spielmodus “Stadt, Land, Pun). Die Pun-Karte ist der Joker und kann einen der 26 Buchstaben vertreten.

Es können auch Karten aus dem Deck genommen werden (empfiehlt sich Q, X, Y rauszunehmen, wenn man nur einsprachig deutsch spielt).

The head-to-head game of deployment, deduction and deception

Break the deadlock in the final days of war. Victory will hinge on the actions of a handful of men – and we women spies… Go head-to-head as you secretly select soldiers with different abilities to engage the enemy.

Each of you will have the opportunity to sabotage your opponent’s missions – using careful deployment, clever deduction and surprising deception. With every enemy soldier you identify, with every advance you rebuff, you’ll tighten the noose, infiltrating further into the enemy camp and taking the Double Agent a step closer to capturing the enemy flag!

Spies & Lies is played in 3 rounds. Each round consists of 3 phases (Deploy, Intel and Mission) which will determine which player can move the Double Agent into enemy territory on the game board. The first player to land on the enemy’s flag with the Double Agent wins (or the player who is closest to doing so when the third round ends).

-description from publisher

Wig Masters is a game for 2-4 players in which 
players take on the roles of wig merchants competing in the high stakes world of powdered wig sales.
  Wear your various fancy wigs to influence the ever changing wig market whilst buying and selling fancy wigs. Players must buy wigs when they are cheap and sell them when they are fashionable to make the most money and win.
  The game is a streamlined stock market game in which players will buy low and sell high from the market to earn money.
  Each Round consists of four phases;

     Players choose a wig to wear for the Round that will determine their turn order and special ability.
     Market demand is determined.
     Players sell wigs to the market.
     Players buy wigs from the market.


Simple rules, deep strategy, brisk playtime. 
 —description from the publisher

Plan, roll, hope! With a little luck and skill, players will achieve their goals in Lost Cities: Auf Schatzsuche ("Lost Cities: On a Treasure Hunt"). In the game, 2-4 players use tiles to set different expedition routes to take them to remote locations around the world. To succeed, you must also take a risk when rolling — but every player should be on guard because your competitors pursue the same goals.

The festival of lights is getting closer. You can breathe happiness in the streets, and at any corner, the emotion is contagious for the great moment coming. Players represent fireworks merchants, who like every year, take advantage of the festivity to offer to the curious and devout the fireworks that will give color and joy to the most colorful party of the year.

On your turn; You can expand your gunpowder factories, producing, open a stall in the market to sell your products and go out calling new customers. You have to keep an eye on what your competitors do; since each night, the scoring phase takes place and only those stalls that satisfy the demand of the clients, as well as those who can fill the sky with colors by shooting their fireworks, will score.

The game lasts 4 rounds and the player with the most points will be declared the winner.

Happy Diwali

—description from the designer

Se acerca la fiesta de las luces. Ya se respira alegria en las calles y en cualquier rincón la emoción se contagia para el gran momento que esta por llegar.  Los jugadores representan mercaderes de fuegos artificiales, que, como cada año, aprovechan la festividad para ofrecer a los curiosos y devotos los fuegos artificiales que darán color y alegría a la fiesta más colorida del año.

En tu turno; podrás ampliar tus fabricas de pólvora, producir, abrir tus puestos en el mercado para vender tu producción y salir a captar nuevos clientes. Tienes que estar atento a lo que hacen tus competidores; pues cada noche tendrá lugar una fase de puntuación. Aquellos puestos que puedan satisfacer la demanda de los clientes asi como aquellos que llenen de colores el cielo con sus fuegos artificiales podrán puntuar.

Al cabo de 4 rondas, el jugador con mas puntos será declarado ganador.

Feliz Diwali.

—description from the designer (Spanish)

This is an Unofficial Expansion for a similar game. based on the much loved TV series, the Office. I made these cards in photoshop as a birthday gift for my wife and decided to share them with the world! Thousands of people have since enjoyed them!

It contains 180 original cards based on The Office TV show.  (144 white, 36 black)

—description from the publisher

A brand new game from the creators of Paper Against The Office!  Parks Against Recreation is the next great game you should have on your shelf at home!

It contains 36 Black Cards and 144 White Cards.Card sizes are the standard 2.5"x3.5"

—description from the publisher

A fun filled, exciting game of touring historic Lowell, Massachusetts visiting historic sites, local businesses & collecting souvenirs. Be part of the famous Lowell Kinetic Sculpture Race, Walk through Kerouac Park, Visit Whistler's House, or Enjoy an outside concert at Boarding House Park.

Players move around a board of historic places in the city of Lowell, MA.  They are tourists collecting special souvenirs that they will then get to keep when they finally return home.

The object of the game is to tour Lowell, visit the 6 historic sites with the green bar above and purchase a souvenir. The first tourist to collect all 6 different souvenirs and return home wins.
